top_categories.workout_context: BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana)’s montana rockies gravel (75%), paved roads (25%) demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana) isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana) rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana)’s montana rockies—mountain technical terrain and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana) when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana). Make this intensity feel like home.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana) — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
At 87 miles, BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana) punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana)’s 9,186ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.

Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana) — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on montana rockies—mountain technical terrain.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana)’s montana rockies—mountain technical terrain delivers on race day.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana)’s 9,186ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana)’s 87 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Moderate altitude at BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana). Arrive 2–3 days early. Reduce intensity expectations by 5–10%. Hydrate aggressively.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at BWR Montana (Belgian Waffle Ride Montana) demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride montana rockies—mountain technical terrain at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: montana rockies gravel (75%), paved roads (25%), mountain terrain. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 87 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 87 miles of montana rockies—mountain technical terrain in Missoula, Montana.
